Do you understand?” The words were brutal, a clinical amputation of her autonomy. It was humiliating. It was also the most profound relief she had ever known. The crushing weight of her financial responsibility, a burden she had carried her entire adult life, was being lifted from her shoulders. He was not giving her a handout; he was taking control to protect his investment. The project wasn’t dead. He hadn’t given up on her. He had simply taken charge.

A single, hot tear traced a path down her cheek, a tear of sheer, bone-deep relief. She quickly wiped it away, but not before he saw it. A flicker of something – not pity, but perhaps empathy – crossed his face before the professional mask slipped back into place. He stood up and gestured towards the live room. “Right,” he said, his voice returning to its familiar, commanding tone. “Your family has a new boiler. Your budget is no longer your problem. You have officially run out of excuses. You told me you let the fear in. Well, it’s not your housemate anymore. It’s just another emotion you can use. You have one job now, Elara. Only one. The work.” He walked over and held the door to the vocal booth open for her. As she walked past him, dazed and trembling, he stopped her with a hand on her arm. His grip was firm. “Don’t thank me,” he said, his voice low and intense. “Just write me a great album.” He released her, and she walked into the padded silence, her mind reeling. She put on the headphones, and his voice came through, crisp and clear, as if the last half-hour had never happened. “’Kingdom of Slate and Cloud’. From the top. And this time, I want to hear the fear. I want to hear the relief. I want to hear the price of it all in your voice. Make it sing.”The headphones felt like a clamp on her skull, the padded silence a roaring in her ears. Paul’s voice, stripped of all its recent intensity and returned to a flat, professional command, was the only thing that existed. *Make it sing.* The instruction was absurd, impossible. Her throat was a knot of unshed tears, her body a taut wire of shame and adrenaline. How could she possibly produce a single, clean note when she was fracturing into a thousand pieces? She opened her mouth, a hollow, defeated gesture, expecting nothing to come out but a dry, pathetic croak.

But the music started, the sparse, melancholic intro to ‘Kingdom of Slate and Cloud’. And when the moment came for her to enter, something other than her conscious will took over. The voice that emerged was not her own. It was a raw, wounded thing, the sound of a frayed rope about to snap. She didn't try to control it, didn't try to make it pretty. She simply opened the door, as Paul had commanded, and let the chaos of the last seventy-two hours flood into the melody. The fear of the cold, the shame of the plumber's quote, the dizzying, terrifying relief of Paul’s intervention—it was all there. When she reached the high note, the one that had been her undoing, she didn’t soar. Her voice broke, shattering on the note with a raw, ugly beauty, like a shard of glass catching a flicker of light. It wasn’t a failure; it was a confession. It was the sound of the price she had paid. She sang the rest of the song from that broken place, and when the final note faded, she leaned her forehead against the cool metal of the microphone, utterly spent, her body trembling with the aftershocks of the emotional exorcism.

The silence from the control room was absolute. There was no praise, no "well done". There was only the quiet, professional click of the intercom. "Sam," Paul's voice said, flat and businesslike. "Mark that. That's the one." And then to Elara, his tone unchanged, "Take five. There's tea in the kitchen." The sheer, anticlimactic normality of it was more grounding than any compliment could have been. He hadn't praised her emotional turmoil; he had simply captured it, catalogued it, and moved on. It was raw material, and they had just mined a particularly rich vein. She stumbled out of the live room, her legs unsteady, and made her way to the small, cluttered kitchen. Sam, the bearded engineer, was already there, filling the kettle. He didn't look at her, but as he spooned coffee into a mug, he spoke to the wall. "That was a hell of a take," he muttered, his voice a low rumble. "Gave me goosebumps." Coming from the taciturn engineer, the words landed with the weight of a standing ovation.

The new regime began the next morning. Sitting at her kitchen table, Elara composed the most humiliating email of her life. Her fingers hovered over the keyboard, her face hot with shame. It felt like standing in a dole queue, presenting her poverty for inspection. *Hi Sam,* she typed. *Paul said I should send a weekly budget. Train fare to Sheffield (2 days): £38. Weekly food shop: £50. Contribution to household bills: £40. Total: £128.* She stared at the stark, pathetic list, a forensic accounting of her small life. It laid her bare. With a deep breath that felt like swallowing jagged stones, she hit send. The reply came less than five minutes later. There was no text, just a subject line: ‘BACS Transfer Notification’. A moment later, her banking app pinged. The amount of £128.00 had appeared in her current account. The transaction was swift, impersonal, and utterly efficient. It was a lifeline, but it felt like a leash.

The boiler was installed two days later. Two men in smart, navy-blue overalls arrived in a clean, new van. They worked with a quiet, swift competence that was a world away from the cheerful chaos of the local plumber. They laid dust sheets, spoke in low, professional tones, and by mid-afternoon, a new, gleaming white box was humming quietly in the cupboard, and hot water was flowing from the taps for the first time in a week. The house began to fill with a slow, pervasive warmth that felt both miraculous and deeply unsettling. Her mother watched the entire process from the living room doorway, her arms crossed, her face a mask of profound suspicion. She did not speak to the men, and when they had gone, she did not comment on the warmth. That evening, as they sat in the blessedly warm living room, she finally broke her silence. "So that's it, then?" she said, her voice tight. "We just take his charity? A strange man buys us a boiler. What does he expect in return, Elara?" Elara sighed, the conversation she had been dreading was finally here. "It's not charity, Mum. It's a production cost. He said he can't have his artist getting pneumonia." "His artist," her mother repeated, the words tasting like ash in her mouth. "You're his property. He buys you a boiler, he tells you how much money you're allowed for a loaf of bread. That's not a job, Elara. That's ownership." The accusation hung in the warm air, ugly and undeniable. The warmth in the house suddenly felt bought and paid for at a price Elara couldn't calculate.

Freed from the immediate, gnawing terror of financial ruin, but yoked to this new, humiliating dependency, the music became her only refuge, the only place where she had any agency. Paul's instruction to let the fear sing for its supper had unlocked a new, darker, and more honest vein of writing. She stopped trying to write beautiful songs. She started trying to write true ones. One night, staring at the sterile, impersonal notification from the bank on her phone, she began to write a new song. It wasn't about the moors or the mills. It was about the cold, brutal arithmetic of her new life. The lyrics were stark, confessional, a list of transactions. *'Itemised, line by line / A weekly wage for peace of mind / The cost of heating, cost of bread / The silent ledger in my head.'* It was an ugly song, stripped of all poetry, its melody built around a tense, repetitive three-chord pattern that felt like a trapped nerve. It was the truest thing she had ever written.

She took it to Sheffield the following week, her heart hammering with a different kind of fear. This wasn't a song she was proud of; it was a raw, open wound she was presenting for inspection. She sang it for Paul in the live room, just her and the acoustic guitar, her voice flat and unadorned, every word a stark admission of her new, managed existence. She didn't dare look at him. When she finished, the silence was long and heavy. She expected a rebuke, a lecture on professionalism, on gratitude. Instead, his voice came through the headphones, quieter than she had ever heard it. "That one cost you something," he said. "We can hear it." He paused. "It’s a hard listen. But it’s honest. It’s the next track on the album." He was not just her producer, her investor, her financial controller. In that moment, he was her witness. And the shared, unspoken understanding of the cost of the work was a bond stronger than any contract.The recording of the song she had bleakly titled ‘The Ledger’ was a stark and brutal affair. Unlike the other tracks, which were gradually being clothed in layers of cello, fiddle, and warm organ sounds, Paul insisted this one remain naked. There was no drum loop for her to cling to, no friendly instrument to converse with. It was just Elara, her acoustic guitar, and a single, unforgiving microphone in the dead, silent room. Paul’s instruction from the control room was simple and cold. “Don’t try to sing it. Just state it. Like you’re reading an invoice. The emotion is in the facts.” She played the tense, repetitive chord pattern, her fingers stiff in the pressurised quiet, and recited the lyrics, her voice deliberately flat and devoid of melody. *‘Itemised, line by line / A weekly wage for peace of mind.’* Each word was a small, hard stone she was forced to place on a scale. It was a performance of anti-performance, a draining and humiliating process of stripping away every artistic impulse, every shred of vanity, leaving only the cold, unvarnished truth of the lyric. After the final, stark chord faded, the silence from the control room was absolute. She didn't need to see Paul to know he had what he wanted. He had captured the sound of her humiliation, the precise timbre of her gilded cage.

Life under the new financial regime was a study in quiet efficiency and profound mortification. Every Monday morning, she would compose the email to Sam, the list of her basic needs feeling more like a parole hearing with each passing week. The swift, impersonal transfer of funds was both a relief and a constant, low-level humiliation. It removed the terror of the overdraft, but it installed a new, quieter shame in its place. The money was no longer hers to manage, to worry over, or even to feel proud of. It was a resource that was allocated to her, like rations. Her mother never mentioned the weekly budget, but Elara felt her watchful eyes, her silent judgment on this new form of dependency. The warmth from the new boiler, once a source of open conflict, became a quiet, unacknowledged fact of their lives, a constant, humming reminder of the deal that had been struck. One afternoon, Elara came home to find a small pot of winter pansies on the kitchen windowsill, their cheerful, purple faces a jarring splash of colour against the grey Milton drizzle. Her mother was wiping down the counter, her back to the flowers. “They were reduced at the market,” she said, her voice defensive, as if caught in an act of reckless extravagance. Elara just nodded, her throat tight. It was the first time in years she had seen her mother buy something that wasn't strictly necessary. It was a tiny, fragile bloom of security, paid for with her daughter’s autonomy.

The creative freedom this new arrangement provided was undeniable, but it was a freedom that came with a heavy psychological price. The studio, once a refuge from the pressures of her life, was now inextricably linked to them. Paul was no longer just a producer; he was the architect of her managed existence. The power imbalance was a constant, unspoken presence in the room, altering their dynamic. He would push her to find a rawer, more honest vocal take, and she would feel a flash of resentment, a rebellious urge to ask if this was what her weekly allowance was paying for. But the resentment was always overwhelmed by the fierce, protective instinct he showed for the music. He was ruthless in his pursuit of the album's truth. During a playback of ‘Kingdom of Slate and Cloud,’ Sam, the engineer, suggested adding a touch of reverb to Elara’s vocal on the fractured high note, to "soften the edge". Paul cut him off with a look that could have stripped paint. “No,” he said, his voice quiet but absolute. “The edge is the point. We’re not making a pop record, Sam. We’re making a scar.” The fierce, uncompromising defence of her most vulnerable moment silenced her resentment. He was not her keeper; he was the guardian of the work, and her personal feelings were secondary to that shared, sacred purpose.

This strange, contradictory existence, suspended between creative liberation and personal constraint, began to seep into her writing. The train journey, the two-hour transit between her two lives, became a fertile ground for ideas. It was a space that belonged to neither Milton nor Sheffield, a place of pure transition. She would sit with her notebook, the hard case of her guitar beside her, and watch the world slide by, feeling like a ghost haunting the space between her past and her future. A new song began to form, not about a place, but about the feeling of being in-between. It was a traveller’s song, its rhythm mirroring the steady, hypnotic clatter of the train wheels. The lyrics were a series of fleeting images seen through the window: a kestrel hovering over a motorway embankment, a row of houses with their backs turned, a lone figure walking a dog in a deserted park. It was a song about motion, about being neither here nor there, about the strange, lonely freedom of being a passenger in your own life.

She brought the song, ‘Passenger’, to the studio, playing it for Paul with a new, quiet confidence. It was less of a confession than ‘The Ledger’ and less rooted than ‘Drystone’. It was a sketch, an observation. He listened intently, then picked up his own guitar. “The rhythm is key,” he said, tapping a pattern on the body of his instrument. “It needs to feel relentless, like the train tracks. It shouldn't be comfortable.” They spent the day working on it, building the song around a driving, almost motorik acoustic guitar pattern that created a sense of constant, unstoppable movement. Catrin, the fiddle player, was in for the day, and Paul asked her to add not a melody, but a series of long, soaring drones that hung over the track like the passing landscape, shifting and changing subtly with the chords. The song was transforming into a hypnotic, atmospheric piece that perfectly captured the feeling of being adrift. As Elara sang the lyrics in the vocal booth, the music swelling around her, she realised that she had managed to turn the very feeling of being trapped between two worlds into a thing of expansive, lonely beauty. She had taken the bars of her cage and woven them into a song. It was a small, quiet act of alchemy, a moment of turning constraint into art. It wasn't freedom, not yet, but it was the next best thing. It was control.The end of winter brought with it a change in the light, a thin, watery gold that slanted through the studio’s high, grimy windows in the late afternoons. The seasons had turned, and with them, the album. It was no longer a scattered collection of battles and breakthroughs; it had mass and momentum. On the large corkboard in the control room, Paul had pinned up a dozen index cards, each bearing the title of a song in his sharp, blocky handwriting. The running order was a narrative, a map of the emotional terrain they had traversed. It started with the frantic, uphill escape of ‘Grey Scar’ and ended, for now, with the stark, bleak accounting of ‘The Ledger’. It was a powerful, cohesive, and deeply melancholy body of work. It was also incomplete. There was a single, glaring empty space at the bottom of the board, a final, unanswered question.

The pressure to answer that question fell on Elara like a physical weight. The frantic, deadline-driven energy that had fuelled the last few months had left her creatively and emotionally hollowed out. She felt like a wrung-out cloth, every memory, every observation, every secret shame and hidden joy squeezed out of her and captured on tape. She would sit for hours with her guitar, her fingers moving numbly over the familiar chord shapes, but the well of inspiration was dry. The moors, once her sanctuary and her source, offered no new revelations. Her runs became joyless, mechanical exercises, her feet crunching on the shale path with a dull, repetitive thud that held no rhythm, no new song. She had told all her stories. She had nothing left to give.

Paul, with his usual unnerving perception, sensed her depletion. He didn’t push or chide. He simply called her into the control room one afternoon, gesturing to the track-listing on the board. “The album works as it is,” he said, his tone pragmatic. “It’s a complete statement. It starts with you running from your life and ends with you being owned by it. It’s honest. It’s also utterly fucking miserable.” He turned to face her, his gaze direct. “It’s a cage door swinging shut. As a producer, I respect that. As a listener, I want to know what happens the next day. The story isn’t finished, Elara. We need the last page.” His words weren’t an accusation; they were a diagnosis. He wasn’t asking her for another song. He was asking her for an ending, and she didn’t have one.

For days, she was adrift. She sifted through her father’s notebooks, hoping to find a borrowed spark, but his half-finished verses only echoed her own sense of incompletion. She listened back to the rough mixes of the album, hoping to find a loose thread she could pull, but the work felt sealed, finished, a closed loop of struggle and survival. The answer, when it came, was not from a song, but from a picture. She came home one evening to find Leo at the kitchen table, his face alight with a rare, unselfconscious pride. He had finished his major project for his art class. He had laid it out across the entire table, a series of a dozen small, square canvases. It was a visual narrative of Milton. It started with a dark, almost abstract rendering of the mill towers, oppressive and monolithic. The subsequent paintings depicted the sullen, defiant faces in The Spinner’s Arms, the endless, repetitive pattern of the terraced roofs, the wild, windswept emptiness of the moors. The final canvas, however, was a surprise. It was a painting of the reservoir at dawn, the water a perfect, still mirror reflecting a sky of impossible, brilliant orange. It was a landscape devoid of people, of buildings, of struggle. It was just water and light. “It’s not an escape,” Leo explained, his voice full of the earnest conviction of a true artist. “It’s a different view. It’s always been there. You just have to be there at the right time to see it.”

His words, simple and profound, struck Elara with the force of a revelation. She had been so focused on the run up, on the fight, on the grim reality of the valley, that she had forgotten about the dawn. She had forgotten about the moments of pure, unadorned beauty that existed alongside the grit and the grime. The last song wasn't about the struggle. It was about what came after. Or rather, what was always there, in the midst of it. That night, she picked up her guitar, her fingers no longer fumbling, but moving with a quiet purpose. She found a new chord progression, one that didn’t descend into melancholy or drive forward with tense energy, but simply rose, like a slow, ascending scale. The melody that came was simple, almost a lullaby. The song was not about running away, or even about the strength to endure. It was a song about the conscious choice to see the light, a quiet hymn to the shard of broken mirror that could, at the right time, reflect the whole sky.

The final recording session felt less like work and more like a gathering of the clan. Paul, in a rare act of sentimentality, had arranged for both Misha and Catrin to be there on the same day. The atmosphere in the studio was warm, relaxed, tinged with the bittersweet feeling of an impending farewell. Elara stood in the vocal booth, but it no longer felt like an isolation chamber. Through the glass, she could see the family that had, piece by piece, built her album. She sang the new song, which she had called ‘Reservoir Light’. Her voice was clear, steady, and unadorned, stripped of the raw, broken textures of the earlier songs. It was the sound of healing. Misha’s cello provided a single, deep, foundational drone, the sound of the ancient land beneath the water. Catrin’s fiddle, instead of its usual wild dancing, played a gentle, soaring counter-melody that felt like the light spreading across the sky. Paul’s acoustic guitar provided the simple, ascending chords, and Sam sat at the desk, his eyes closed, just listening. They recorded it in two takes. It didn't need any more. It was already home.

Later, as the winter light faded from the high windows, the five of them gathered in the control room. The air was thick with a nervous, sacred anticipation. “Right,” Paul said, his voice softer than usual. “Let’s listen to the record.” He dimmed the main lights, leaving only the soft, ambient glow from the mixing desk, and pressed play. The opening, frantic acoustic guitar of ‘Grey Scar’ filled the room. Elara closed her eyes. It was the strangest, most profound journey of her life. She heard her own story told back to her, but transformed, elevated. She heard the climb, the community, the history, the pain, the claustrophobia, and the lonely motion. She heard the pub’s defiant laughter in Catrin’s fiddle, the weight of the hills in Misha’s cello, the grit of the town in the raw edge of her own voice. The songs flowed one into the next, a seamless, heartbreaking, and ultimately defiant narrative. When the final, gentle notes of ‘Reservoir Light’ faded into silence, no one spoke. The silence was not empty; it was full of the completed work. Elara opened her eyes to find tears tracking silently down her face. They were not tears of sadness, but of a catharsis so deep it felt like her bones were settling into a new, stronger alignment.

The spell was broken by Paul clearing his throat. He ejected a CD from the console burner and, with a black marker, wrote a single word on its silver surface: ‘ALBUM’. He handed it to her. The disc was warm, a small, fragile vessel containing the entire, tumultuous world they had created. “It’s done,” he said, his voice back to its usual gruffness. “My job is over. Now the next phase begins. The mixing, the mastering, the press. The waiting. It’s out of our hands now.” He walked her to the heavy black door of the studio, the threshold she had crossed so many times in fear and hope and despair. “You made a great record, Elara,” he said, his hand on the door. He looked her in the eye, and the usual professional distance was gone, replaced by a simple, profound respect. “It was worth it.”

On the train back to Milton, Elara sat with the CD case held tight in her hands. The sun had set, and the darkened window reflected her own pale, tired, but peaceful face. The rhythmic clatter of the wheels on the track was no longer a driving, anxious beat, but a gentle, lulling cadence. She was not running away, nor was she commuting to a job. She was simply going home. The work that had consumed her, that had reshaped her life and her soul, was finished. The silence that awaited her in Milton was no longer an empty void to be filled, but a quiet space in which to breathe. The album was done. A whole new, terrifying, and unknown silence was about to begin.

The rhythm was the only thing that mattered. Left foot, right foot, crunching on the shale path that cut a grey scar across the green-brown flank of the moor. The air was thin up here, and sharp, tasting of wet earth and the distant, metallic tang of the town festering in the valley below. Elara’s lungs burned, a familiar and almost comforting fire. It was a clean pain, a simple pain. You run, you hurt, you keep running, you hurt less. Or maybe you just get used to the hurting. She wasn’t sure which. Her ponytail, a whip of dark brown, flicked against the collar of her worn windbreaker, keeping its own frantic time.

This was her sanctuary. Not the cramped, two-up two-down terrace house with its permanent odour of damp and her mum’s weary sighs. Not the claustrophobic streets of Milton, where every other shopfront was boarded up and the ghosts of the cotton mills watched from their soot-blackened brick towers. Here, with only the wind and the stoic, grazing sheep for company, she was just a body in motion. A machine of bone and muscle, fuelled by a stubbornness that was her primary inheritance. The beat of her feet on the ground was a drum, and her heart was the frantic, desperate solo played over the top of it.

And sometimes, when the wind was right and there wasn't a soul for miles, she’d let the other thing out.

It started as a hum, a low vibration in her chest that harmonised with the thud of her trainers. It was a melody she’d heard on the radio, a sad, soaring thing that didn’t belong in the grime of her daily life. The hum grew, pushing past the tightness in her throat, past the ragged gasps for air. Then, she opened her mouth and sang. The sound was swallowed instantly by the vast, indifferent sky, a thread of silver lost in the grey expanse. Her voice wasn't a runner's voice. It wasn't clipped or efficient. It was a long, aching ribbon of sound, full of a longing she couldn't put a name to. It was a different kind of escape, a different kind of flight. Running made her body feel weightless; singing made her soul feel it.

She crested the rise, the point she always aimed for, and the whole of Milton was laid out beneath her like a spill of grubby Lego bricks. The reservoir glinted like a shard of broken mirror. She slowed to a walk, hands on her hips, dragging in the cold, cleansing air. The song died in her throat, tucked away again in its secret compartment. Down there was reality. Down there was Leo’s school uniform, which was getting too small, and the electricity bill sitting on the mantelpiece like a threat. Down there was her shift at The Spinner’s Arms, pulling pints for men with hands permanently stained with oil and faces etched with a familiar disappointment.

Her run back down was faster, gravity pulling her insistently towards the life she’d just run away from. The descent was always the hardest part. Going up was a fight. Coming down was a surrender.

The back door complained with its usual screech as she let herself in. The house was quiet, for now. Mum would be at the care home, her own day of relentless, draining work just beginning. Leo was at school. The quiet was a brief, precious gift. She peeled off her sweaty layers in the tiny kitchen, the lino cold under her bare feet. The smell of burnt toast lingered in the air from a rushed breakfast. On the small, formica-topped table, beside a wilting pot plant, was a crumpled flyer. She’d picked it up from the community centre noticeboard yesterday, drawn by the lurid, hopeful starburst in the corner.

‘NORTHERN VOICE,’ it screamed in a cheap, gaudy font. ‘IS THE NEXT STAR FROM THE NORTH? REGIONAL HEATS – MILTON.’

She’d laughed when she took it, a short, sharp sound. A singing competition. It was the sort of thing girls from a different world did. Girls with proper lessons, with confidence that hadn't been ground down by circumstance. Girls who didn’t have to choose between a new pair of running shoes and a winter coat. Still, she’d folded it and shoved it in her pocket. A stupid, childish impulse.

Now, in the silence of the kitchen, it seemed to mock her. She picked it up, smoothing the creases. The first heat was in three weeks. At the Assembly Rooms, a place that usually hosted bingo nights and wedding receptions for people who couldn't afford anything better. The grand prize was a recording contract and a cash sum that made her head spin. But that was a universe away. The prize for winning the Milton heat was a guaranteed spot in the grand final in Manchester. Manchester. It might as well have been the moon.

She thought of her voice on the moor, free and untethered. She thought of it in the shower, bouncing off the damp-spotted tiles, the only place it ever felt truly big. What would it sound like in a hall, with microphones and strangers? The thought sent a jolt of pure terror through her, followed by a low, persistent thrum of something else. Something that felt dangerously like hope.

"Don't be stupid, El," she muttered to the empty room. Her voice was flat, all the music gone. She tossed the flyer towards the bin, but it missed, fluttering to the floor like a wounded bird. She left it there.

The pub was loud that evening, a thick soup of noise and overlapping conversations. Elara moved through it with the practiced economy of a seasoned pro, her mind a running tally of orders. Two pints of bitter, a gin and slimline, packet of crisps. Smile. Take the money. Give the change. Repeat. The faces blurred into one another. It was a job, that’s all. It paid for her and Leo’s food, and it chipped away at the mountain of bills. It didn't require her to be anyone.

"Bit of a dreamer today, aren't we, love?"

Brenda, the landlady, nudged her, her voice a gravelly boom that could cut through the thickest pub roar. She was a woman built like a brick outhouse, with a peroxide blonde beehive that defied gravity and a heart that was, surprisingly, not made of stone.

"Just tired," Elara said, pulling another pint, watching the foam rise with practiced precision.

"Running again this morning, were we? Up on the tops?" Brenda nodded, wiping the bar with a rag. "You'll run yourself into the ground one of these days. There's more to life than punishing your own two feet, you know."

Elara just shrugged. How could she explain it? How could she explain that the punishment was the point?

Later, during a rare lull, her eyes fell on the small, makeshift stage in the corner. On Thursdays, it was karaoke night. A parade of the brave and the drunk, murdering classic songs to the delight of their mates. She’d always found it excruciating, a public execution of music. But tonight, she looked at it differently. She pictured the microphone, the two speakers crackling on either side. She imagined the Assembly Rooms. Bigger, but the same principle. A stage. A voice. An audience.

"Go on," a voice slurred from the end of the bar. It was old George, a regular who had been a fixture since the pub was built. "Give us a song, Elara. You're always so quiet. Bet you've got a secret warble in you."

A ripple of laughter went through the few remaining drinkers. Elara’s face flushed hot. "No thanks, George. I'll leave it to the professionals."

"Professionals?" George cackled. "Last week we had Dave from the garage singing 'My Way' like a cat being put in a bag. Go on, love. We're all friends here."

The thought was mortifying. Singing here, in front of these people. Her secret, precious thing, trotted out for the entertainment of a half-drunk pub. But then, Brenda’s words echoed in her head. *There's more to life than punishing your own two feet.* And she saw the flyer again, lying on her kitchen floor. This was nothing. A karaoke machine in a pub. The Assembly Rooms... that was something. But you had to take a first step. Even in running, the first step out the door on a cold morning was the hardest one.

"Alright," she heard herself say, the word a stranger in her own mouth. A small, ragged cheer went up from the regulars.

Brenda’s eyebrows shot up towards her hairline. "You're on, love. What'll it be?"

Her mind went blank. Every song she had ever known vanished in a puff of panic. She could feel her heart starting to pound, a frantic, trapped rhythm against her ribs. This was a mistake. A terrible, humiliating mistake. She opened her mouth to back out, to say she was only joking, but then she saw Leo’s face in her mind. His last school report, glowing with praise for his artwork. The art supplies he wanted, the expensive ones, that she’d had to say no to. The look of quiet understanding on his face, an expression too old for a twelve-year-old.

She took a breath. "Something... something simple," she managed. She scanned the dog-eared songbook Brenda pushed towards her, her finger tracing down the list of over-sung classics. And then she saw it. An old ballad her dad used to sing, a lifetime ago. A song about leaving and home and the pull of the sea. It was sad and simple and it lived somewhere deep inside her.

"That one," she said, her voice barely a whisper.

Brenda squinted. "Bit of a downer, innit? But it's your funeral." She keyed it in.

The first few bars of the synthesised backing track sounded tinny and cheap. Elara walked towards the stage, each step feeling like she was wading through treacle. The sticky floor, the smell of stale beer, the handful of curious faces staring at her. This was it. She took the heavy microphone, its metal cool against her sweating palm. She closed her eyes. She imagined the moor, the wide grey sky, the wind in her ears. She forgot the pub, forgot George and Brenda and the men at the bar. She was somewhere else.

And then she sang.

There was no applause when she finished. Just a thick, profound silence. Elara’s eyes fluttered open. The world rushed back in, loud and bright. Old George was staring into his pint, his shoulders shaking slightly. Brenda was stock-still behind the bar, the rag forgotten in her hand. Two other men were just looking at her, their mouths slightly agape. The silence stretched, and a hot wave of shame washed over her. It was too sad. Too raw. She’d made them uncomfortable. She’d made a fool of herself.

She put the microphone back in its stand with a clatter and practically fled back to the safety of the bar, her face burning. She started wiping the counter, her movements jerky and frantic, unable to look at anyone.

It was Brenda who broke the spell. "Right," she said, her voice strangely thick. "Who's next for a pint?"

No one mentioned it for the rest of the night. But as she was cashing up, Brenda slid a twenty-pound note across the bar. "That's your tips," she said, which was a lie. Elara rarely made a fiver in tips.

"I can't—" Elara started.

"Take it," Brenda said, her gaze firm. "And listen to me. That flyer you were looking at. The singing thing. You're going to do it. That's not a suggestion."

Elara looked from the twenty-pound note to Brenda’s determined face. The fear was still there, a cold knot in her stomach. But for the first time, the tiny, dangerous thrum of hope was louder.

The day of the audition was grey and drizzly, a typical Milton Tuesday. The Assembly Rooms smelled of dust and floor polish. A trestle table had been set up in the foyer, manned by a bored-looking woman with a clipboard who took Elara’s name and handed her a numbered sticker. Number 47. She pressed it onto her grey jumper, the adhesive cold against her chest. She was surrounded by people who looked so much more confident than she felt. Girls with brightly coloured hair and professionally applied makeup, laughing and chatting. Men who looked like they’d been singing in pubs their whole lives. They all had a kind of practiced ease that she lacked. She felt like an impostor, a runner who had wandered into the wrong race.

She found a seat at the back of the hall, clutching her hands in her lap. Her palms were slick with sweat. One by one, the numbers were called. Voices boomed through the speakers, some powerful, some shaky, some painfully off-key. For every person who sounded like they might have a chance, there were three who were clearly deluded. With each one, Elara's anxiety grew. It was so public, so exposed. She felt the urge to bolt, to run back to the safety of the moors where her voice belonged only to her and the sky.

"Number 47?"

The voice from the stage made her jump. It was her turn. Her legs felt like lead as she walked towards the steps at the side of the stage. The hall looked vast and empty from up here. Three figures sat at a table in the gloom, their faces illuminated by the glow of laptops. They were the judges. They didn't look up.

"Name?" one of them asked, a man with a weary voice.

"Elara Vance."

"And what are you singing for us today, Elara Vance?"

She had to clear her throat to speak. "An old folk song. 'The Leaving'." It wasn't the song she’d sung in the pub. This one was different. It was about resilience, not loss. It was a song of the hills, of staying put, of finding beauty in a hard place. It was her song.

"Right. Whenever you're ready."

The instruction was a release. She didn't have to think anymore. She just had to do. She closed her eyes, just as she had in the pub. She pictured the shale path, the burn in her lungs, the view from the top. She took a breath, not a shallow, nervous gasp, but a deep, runner’s breath, from the diaphragm, the kind that fuelled a final sprint.

The first note was pure and clear, cutting through the dusty silence of the hall. It held no fear. It was the sound of the wind over the reservoir, the cry of a kestrel on the wing. It was the stubborn, quiet strength of the heather clinging to the hillside. She poured all of it in. The frustration of her dead-end life, the fierce love for her brother, the memory of her dad’s smile, the ache in her muscles after a ten-mile run. It was everything she couldn't say, transformed into something beautiful. She held the last note, letting it hang in the air, a perfect, shimmering sphere of sound, until her breath finally gave out.

Silence.

Again. That terrifying, unreadable silence. She opened her eyes. The three judges were all looking at her. Actually looking at her. The weary man in the middle had taken off his glasses. The woman next to him had her pen poised over her notepad, but she wasn't writing.

"You run, don't you?" the man said. It wasn't a question.

Elara was so taken aback she could only nod.

"I can hear it," he said, a glimmer of interest in his tired eyes. "The breath control. It's phenomenal. Where did you learn to sing like that?"

"I... I don't know," she stammered. "I just... do."

The judge shared a look with the woman beside him. He scribbled something on his pad. "Thank you, Elara. We'll be in touch."

The dismissal was abrupt. She stumbled off the stage, her cheeks hot, her heart hammering. She didn’t know if it was good or bad. *I can hear the run in your voice.* What did that even mean? She didn't wait around. She pushed open the heavy doors of the Assembly Rooms and ran. She didn't stop until she was home, bursting through the back door, gasping for air.

Leo was at the kitchen table, sketching in a notepad. He looked up, his eyes wide. "Did you do it? How did it go?"

"I don't know," she panted, leaning against the counter. "I think I made a fool of myself."

The email arrived three days later. Elara saw the subject line – ‘Northern Voice Audition’ – and her stomach plummeted. She let it sit in her inbox for a full hour, making tea, tidying a room that was already tidy, before she finally clicked on it.

*Dear Elara Vance,*

*Thank you for your audition... We were extremely impressed with the quality of talent in Milton... a very high standard...*

She scanned the polite, generic phrases, her heart sinking. It was a no. It was a fancy, pre-written no.

*...For this reason, we are absolutely delighted to inform you that you have successfully secured a place in the Northern Voice Grand Final...*

Elara read the sentence again. And again. The words swam, refusing to lock into place. *Delighted to inform you... secured a place... Grand Final.* It couldn't be right. It had to be a mistake. A typo. They must have sent the email to the wrong person. But there was her name. Elara Vance. The date and time of the final in Manchester. The rules and a list of approved songs. It was real.

A slow, incredulous smile spread across her face. It felt alien, like she was using muscles she hadn't tried in years. She had done it. She had actually done it. A bubble of pure, unadulterated joy rose in her chest, so powerful it felt like it might lift her off the ground. She let out a laugh, a loud, gasping sound of disbelief.

"What is it?" Leo asked, drawn by the noise.

She turned to him, the screen of her phone held out like a trophy. "I got in," she said, her voice giddy. "Leo, I got in! I'm in the final!"

He squinted at the phone and then his face broke into a huge, unrestrained grin. "You did it! I told you! I knew you would!" He launched himself at her, wrapping his arms around her waist in a fierce hug. She hugged him back, lifting him off his feet and spinning him around the tiny kitchen, both of them laughing. For a few perfect, dizzying moments, there were no bills on the mantelpiece, no damp in the walls, no aching exhaustion. There was just the impossible, shimmering reality of a dream she had never even dared to have, coming true. The final. In Manchester. She was going.

The laughter faded, and the kitchen, with its lingering smell of burnt toast, seemed to shrink back to its normal size. Elara re-read the email, her eyes snagging on the practical details. The final was in Manchester. On a Saturday. Soundcheck at 2 p.m., the main event at 8 p.m. It was a whole day. A whole day away from Milton, from Leo, from her shift at the pub. The train fare alone would cost more than she earned in two nights behind the bar. And what would she wear? Her entire wardrobe consisted of worn running gear, faded jeans, and her black work trousers. Nothing a ‘Grand Finalist’ would wear. The bright, shimmering bubble of joy didn't pop, but it deflated, tethered to the grubby kitchen lino by a dozen worrying, practical strings.

Her mum arrived home late, the lines of fatigue carved deeper than usual around her eyes. Elara waited until she was settled at the table with her customary mug of tea, staring at the wall for a full ten minutes to let the noise of her day at the care home subside. “Mum,” Elara started, her voice barely more than a whisper. “I have something to tell you.” She explained it all, starting with the flyer and ending with the email, her phone held out as evidence. She watched her mum’s face, trying to decipher the flicker of emotions. Pride? Yes, she saw a glimmer of it, a brief softening of her mother's mouth. But it was quickly submerged by something else, something familiar and heavy. Worry.

“Manchester?” her mum said, her voice flat with exhaustion. “Elara, that’s… that’s lovely, pet. But we can’t afford…” She trailed off, gesturing vaguely at the peeling paint and the ever-present stack of bills on the mantelpiece. “It’s a wonderful dream, a lovely idea. But don’t go getting your hopes up. These things… they’re not for people like us.” The words were a quiet slap, not meant to be unkind, just the weary truth of her mother’s world, a world where hope was a luxury you couldn’t afford. *People like us.* The phrase echoed the one in Elara’s own head from when she first saw the flyer, and the fragile hope in her chest felt a little more bruised and foolish.

The atmosphere at The Spinner’s Arms was a world away. When Elara shared the news with Brenda, the landlady let out a whoop that made half the pub jump and rattle the optics. “I knew it! I told you, didn’t I? Our Elara!” She grabbed Elara in a bone-crushing hug that smelled of hairspray and chip fat, her peroxide beehive threatening to collapse. Beaming at the regulars, who were all now looking over with interest, she thumped a hand on the bar. “Right then! This calls for a collection! We’re getting our girl to that final!” Before Elara could protest, Brenda had grabbed an empty pickle jar, scrawled ‘ELARA’S MANCHESTER FUND’ on a piece of cardboard with a thick bingo marker, and plonked it proudly on the bar. Old George was the first to contribute, fumbling in his worn jacket and dropping a crumpled ten-pound note inside. The shame Elara had expected to feel was entirely absent, replaced by a sudden, surprising wave of warmth that stung her eyes.

The next two weeks were a strange tightrope walk between two different lives. By day she pulled pints, mopped sticky floors, and did her sums, calculating and recalculating the cost of everything. In the mornings, she still ran the moors, chasing down the familiar, cleansing pain. But now there was a new urgency to it. She tried to sing as she ran, to recapture the feeling from the audition. The judge's words haunted her: *I can hear the run in your voice.* She pushed herself up the steepest inclines, feeling the controlled burn in her diaphragm, and then tried to let a note fly, desperate to understand the connection between the physical strain and the sound she produced. Some days it worked; her voice soared, clear and strong, powered by her lungs and the wild landscape. Other days, it was just a breathless, pathetic squeak, and she felt like a complete and utter fraud.

At home, her only private practice space was the bathroom. With the door locked and the shower running to disguise the sound from the neighbours, she sang to the cracked tiles and the stubborn spots of black mould on the grout. She worked her way through the list of pre-approved songs sent in the email, a bland selection of modern pop hits and over-sung classic ballads. They all felt wrong, like trying to squeeze her feet into someone else’s shoes. They were songs of easy love and manufactured heartbreak, of a world she didn't know, and the words felt like lies in her mouth. She thought of the raw honesty of the song she’d sung in the pub, of the simple strength of the folk song from her audition. None of these sterile, approved songs felt true. The panic began to set in, a low, cold hum beneath the surface of everything she did.

Leo was her anchor in the swirling chaos of her own head. He was utterly, unshakably convinced of her impending stardom. He spent hours at the kitchen table, filling page after page of his sketchbook. He designed a logo for her, a soaring bird with its wings shaped like soundwaves. He drew a stage outfit – a simple, dark dress with a silver sash, "like the silver thread of your voice in the sky," he explained with the deadly seriousness only a twelve-year-old can muster. One evening, as she sat defeated, staring blankly at the song list, he pushed his sketchbook towards her. On the page was a drawing of the moor, the grey shale path a scar across the green-brown flank. Beneath it, he'd carefully written a line from a song she sometimes hummed without realising, an old, obscure folk song her dad used to love. A song about the stubborn beauty of a harsh landscape. *'The heather and the stone remain.'* It was not on the list.

"That's the one you should sing," Leo said simply, tapping the page. "It sounds like you." The thought was terrifying. To go against the official list, to choose something they hadn’t approved, was to risk everything. It was breaking the rules. It was practically asking for disqualification before she even opened her mouth. But the song… it fit. It was a song of resilience, not escape. It wasn't about running away from a hard life, but about the strength it takes to stay and endure it. It was a song about Milton, about the moors, about her family. It was the other side of the coin to 'The Leaving'. It was the run in her voice, the stubbornness, the choice to keep fighting up the hill instead of surrendering to the descent.

The night before she was due to leave for Manchester, she emptied the pickle jar onto the kitchen table. It was a small mountain of coins and crumpled notes, smelling faintly of brine and stale beer. It was more than enough for the train fare, a decent meal, and maybe even a new top to wear. Brenda had shoved another fifty pounds into her hand at the end of her last shift, refusing any argument. "Break a leg, love," she'd said, her voice gruff with an emotion she tried to hide. "And don't you dare come back without winning." Staring at the money, a tangible testament to the faith of pub regulars and a formidable landlady, Elara felt a new kind of pressure. It wasn't just her own secret, childish hope on the line anymore. She was carrying a small piece of all of theirs, too.

She folded the money carefully and put it in a worn envelope. Then she sat down, took out her phone, and composed a short, polite email to the Northern Voice production team. *'Re: Song Choice for Elara Vance.'* Her finger hovered over the send button, a tremor running through her hand. It was a risk. A huge one. But running up the moor in the freezing wind was a risk. Singing in the pub was a risk. Every good thing, she was beginning to realise, started with a step into the unknown. She closed her eyes, took a deep, steadying breath, and pressed send.

The train pulled out of Milton station with a familiar shudder, leaving behind the soot-blackened brick and the steep, green-brown hills that cupped the town like a protective, if slightly grimy, hand. Elara had a window seat, the pickle-jar money tucked safely in the inner pocket of her new coat – a simple, dark grey wool coat Brenda had insisted on buying for her from a catalogue, dismissing Elara’s protests with a wave of her hand. Leo and her mum had seen her off on the platform. Leo had been vibrating with excitement, pressing a small, smooth stone from the moor into her hand. "For luck," he'd whispered fiercely. Her mum had just hugged her, a quick, tight embrace that said everything she couldn't. *Be careful. Don't get hurt. Come home.*

As the train picked up speed, the terraced houses gave way to warehouses, then to patches of scruffy woodland, and finally to the flat, sprawling plains of Cheshire. The landscape flattened, the horizon widened, and Elara felt a strange sense of agoraphobia. She was used to the enclosed, vertical world of the moors, where you always knew where you were in relation to the valley. Out here, everything seemed vast and anchorless. She clutched the stone in her pocket, its familiar texture a small piece of home. There had been no reply to her email. Not a word. The silence felt ominous, a blank space where either acceptance or rejection could be written. She was walking into the lion's den with a song they hadn't approved, fuelled by nothing more than a gut feeling and a twelve-year-old's drawing. The thought made her stomach feel like it was full of fizzing, anxious bees.

The venue in Manchester was a different world from the dusty Assembly Rooms. It was an old concert hall, refurbished into a gleaming temple of glass and steel. Polished floors reflected a constellation of spotlights. Crews of people with headsets and clipboards scurried about with an air of frantic importance. The other finalists were gathered in a large, bright green room, a space that was supposed to feel relaxing but was thick with a potent cocktail of perfume, hairspray, and raw ambition. They were a glossy, confident bunch. There was a boyband with matching leather jackets and meticulously gelled hair, a girl with a powerful, booming laugh who announced to anyone who would listen that she'd been on two other reality shows, and a man with a guitar who was so handsome it seemed vaguely unfair. They were all talking about vocal coaches and social media followings and their 'brand'. Elara felt like a stray dog that had wandered in by accident. She found a chair in a corner, took out the stone Leo had given her, and rolled it over and over in her palm, trying to breathe like she was on a run.

A harried-looking woman with a headset finally came over, her clipboard a shield against the world. "Elara Vance?" Elara stood up, her heart thumping. "Right. Soundcheck in five. Now, we saw your email." The woman's expression was unreadable. "Bit late in the day to be changing your song choice. It's not on the approved list." This was it. The moment they told her to sing the pop song or go home. Elara braced herself, the words of protest dying in her throat before they were even formed. "But..." the woman continued, tapping her pen on the clipboard. "Paul, our head judge, remembered you from the Milton heat. He said, 'Let the runner sing what she wants'. So, you've got one chance. 'The Heather and the Stone'. Just make sure it's good." The woman gave her a sharp, appraising look and then bustled away, leaving Elara reeling, a dizzying mix of relief and sheer terror washing over her. Paul. The head judge. *Let the runner sing what she wants.* He had remembered her. He had understood. The small, fragile hope she'd been nurturing felt a little less foolish, a little more solid.

Hours later, the time had bled away in a nerve-wracking haze of waiting. Elara, now dressed in a simple, long-sleeved dark blue dress Leo had helped her pick from a charity shop – "the colour of the reservoir at dusk," he'd said – stood in the wings, listening to the roar of the crowd. She was on last. The handsome man with the guitar was just finishing, his voice smooth and professional, earning a huge wave of applause. Through a gap in the heavy velvet curtains, she could see the vast, dark auditorium, a sea of faces lit by the glare of the stage lights. The scale of it was terrifying. It was a million miles from singing to the indifferent sky on the moor. She felt the familiar urge to flee, to find a grey scar of a path and just run until her lungs burned clean.

"And now, for our final contestant of the night," a slick, disembodied voice boomed through the speakers. "From the hills of Milton, please welcome Elara Vance!" A smattering of polite applause rippled through the hall. This was it. The descent. The surrender. Or was it? She remembered running up the hill, the fight, the burn, the moment you push past the pain. This wasn't a surrender. This was the final sprint. She walked out into the blaze of light, her brother's stone clutched tight in her hand. The three judges, including Paul, sat at their glowing desk, their faces serious. She walked to the centre of the stage, to the lone microphone stand. The vast space seemed to press in on her, threatening to swallow her whole.

There was no backing track. She hadn't asked for one. There was only silence. She closed her eyes. She didn't picture the moor this time. She pictured the faces. Leo, his eyes shining with belief. Brenda, thumping the bar, her beehive defiant. Old George, staring into his pint. Her mum, her face etched with worry and a fierce, hidden love. All the people from the pickle jar. The stubborn, disappointed, resilient faces of Milton. This wasn't just for her. She took a breath, not a shallow gasp of fear, but a deep, controlled breath from her diaphragm, the kind that fuelled her runs, the kind that came from a place of strength.

She sang. The first line of 'The Heather and the Stone' was quiet, almost a whisper, yet it carried to the very back of the huge hall. It wasn't a ribbon of silver this time; it was rougher, more textured. It was the sound of shale crunching underfoot, of wind whistling through drystone walls. The song built, note by note, line by line. She poured into it the grit and the grime, the weariness of her mother’s sighs, the sting of the cold air on the tops, the permanent damp of the two-up two-down. But she also poured in the fierce, wild beauty of it all. The stoic sheep, the glint of the reservoir, the stubbornness that was her primary inheritance. It wasn't a song begging for sympathy or pity. It was a statement. *This is where I am from. This is what made me.* Her voice wasn't just a voice anymore; it was a landscape. It held the steep climb and the brief, breathtaking view from the summit. She held the final, quiet note – *'The heather and the stone remain'* – and let it fade into the profound, ringing silence of the hall.

When she opened her eyes, the silence held for a beat longer. It wasn't the awkward, uncomfortable silence of the pub, nor the blank, unreadable silence of the audition. It was a heavy, weighted silence, full of held breath. Then, someone in the audience started to clap. A slow, deliberate clap. Another joined in, and another, and then the entire auditorium erupted. It wasn’t the wild screaming she’d heard for the boyband; it was a deep, rolling wave of applause that seemed to come from the heart. It washed over her, a physical force. She looked at the judges' table. The woman was dabbing at her eyes with a tissue. The other male judge was just shaking his head slowly, a look of stunned respect on his face. Paul was leaning forward, his elbows on the desk, looking directly at her. He wasn't smiling. He was just looking at her, and in his eyes, she saw the same thing she’d seen in Brenda’s, in Leo’s. He saw her. Not an impostor, not a number, not just a runner. He saw a singer. He nodded, once. A small, definitive gesture of acknowledgement. In that moment, surrounded by the roar of strangers, Elara felt more at home than she ever had in her life. The result didn't matter. She had taken her run, and she had sung her truth. She had not surrendered. She had flown.

The wave of sound receded, leaving a ringing in Elara’s ears. She gave a small, jerky nod to the roaring darkness and turned, walking off the stage with legs that felt both light and heavy, as if she were walking on the moon. Back in the dazzling chaos of the wings, the other finalists looked at her with a new, unnerving mix of emotions. The handsome guitarist gave her a slow, appreciative nod. The girl who boasted about her TV experience just stared, her professionally confident smile momentarily wiped from her face, replaced by an expression of pure, unadulterated shock. Elara didn't wait for their comments. She slipped past them, back to the green room, which now felt impossibly loud and garish. She sank into her corner chair, her body trembling with the aftershocks of adrenaline. The stone was still in her hand, now warm from her grip. She had done it. She had sung her song, her way. The feeling was so vast, so complete, that the idea of a winner and a loser felt like a detail from a different, smaller story.

Eventually, a producer with a clipboard herded them all back to the stage. They were lined up under the hot lights, a strange tableau of sequins, leather, and Elara’s charity-shop dress. The slick host reappeared, milking the moment for every drop of manufactured tension, his teeth gleaming. Elara found herself staring out into the dark auditorium, searching for a single face but finding only a shifting, anonymous mass. Her heart, which had been so full of music just minutes before, was now beating a slow, steady rhythm. Whatever happened now was just weather. The mountain was still there.

“And the winner of Northern Voice,” the host boomed, letting the silence stretch until it was thin and brittle, “is… Eclipse!” The name of the boyband detonated in the hall. Confetti cannons fired, showering the four stunned, then ecstatic, young men in glittering paper. The roar from the crowd was deafening as they leaped into the air, hugging each other, crying, and laughing all at once. Cameras swarmed them, the machinery of stardom grinding instantly into gear. Elara watched them, a genuine smile touching her lips. She felt a brief, sharp pang of loss—not for herself, but for Leo, for the easy, transformative magic of the prize money. But the feeling passed as quickly as it came, leaving behind a profound and surprising sense of peace. The boys’ joy was real, and their music, a slick, expertly crafted pop confection, was what this show had always been about. Her song had been an interruption, a piece of wild moorland dropped into a manicured garden.

The other losing contestants were already moving, some pasting on bright smiles to congratulate the winners, others slipping away with the quiet bitterness of a dream deferred. The stage lights dimmed on everyone but the victorious band, and Elara found herself suddenly in the shadows, an afterthought. The spell was broken. She was just Elara Vance from Milton again, a barmaid with a long train ride home. She turned to leave, to gather her coat and the small bag that held her worn running shoes, her gaze already fixed on the familiar, grubby streets of home. The descent was always the hardest part.

“Elara.” The voice was quiet but cut through the din of celebration. She turned. It was Paul, the head judge. He had left the judging desk and was standing a few feet away, his hands in his pockets, looking at her with that same unnerving, direct gaze. The tired weariness she’d seen at the first audition was gone, replaced by a sharp, focused intensity. “A word?” he asked, gesturing towards the relative quiet of the wings. She followed him, her heart starting to beat a little faster now, a nervous, uncertain rhythm. He stopped by a stack of flight cases, away from the frantic energy of the stage crew. “They were never going to pick you,” he said, without preamble. The bluntness of it was almost a relief. “What you do… it’s not for Saturday night television. It’s not easy, it’s not disposable. The label wants a product they can sell next to a pizza, and Eclipse are a very well-made product.”

Elara just nodded, unsure what to say. “So why…?” she started, her voice barely a whisper. “Why did you let me sing that song?”

“Because I wanted to hear it,” he said simply. “Because once in a while, in a hundred auditions that all sound the same, you hear a real voice. A voice that has a story to tell. Your voice has ligature, Elara. It has grit. It’s got the bloody hills in it.” He paused, his eyes searching her face. “That’s rare. It’s valuable. It’s just not valuable to *them*.” He reached into his jacket pocket and pulled out a simple, cream-coloured business card. He held it out to her. ‘Paul Abbott - Kestrel Records’. “That’s my label. It’s small. We don’t have confetti cannons and we can’t make you a millionaire overnight. What we do is make records. Good ones. For people who actually listen to music.”

Elara took the card. The thick, embossed cardstock felt solid and real in her hand, a stark contrast to the flimsy, fluttering confetti still settling on the stage. “I don’t… I don’t understand,” she stammered.

“It’s not an offer of a contract,” he said quickly, managing her expectations with the same directness. “Not yet. It’s an invitation. Come to my studio in Sheffield next week. Bring your songs. The one you sang tonight, the one from the audition. Any others you’ve got locked away. Let’s just sit and play them. No lights, no audience. We’ll see what’s there.” He gave her a small, wry smile. “Then we’ll talk about a contract.” He held her gaze for a moment longer. “What you did tonight was brave. Now the real work starts. Don’t lose your nerve.” And with a final nod, he turned and walked away, disappearing into the backstage labyrinth, leaving Elara staring at the small cream rectangle in her hand. Kestrel Records. A kestrel. The bird she saw soaring over the reservoir.

The late train rattled through the darkness, its rhythmic clatter a comforting, familiar beat. Manchester’s sprawling constellation of lights dwindled behind them, and Elara pressed her forehead against the cool glass of the window, watching her own faint reflection. She was exhausted, every muscle aching with a tension she hadn’t been aware of holding. In her pocket, her fingers were wrapped around two things: the smooth, cool stone from the moor, and the sharp, crisp corner of Paul Abbott’s business card. She didn’t have a giant novelty cheque. She wouldn’t be able to pay off her mum’s debts or buy Leo the art studio he dreamed of. Not yet. But she had something else. It was a quieter hope, a harder-won hope. It wasn't a prize she had been given, but a path she had cleared herself, step by stubborn step.

It was well after one in the morning when she finally walked the deserted streets back to her house. The air was cold, tasting of wet earth and home. The back door complained with its usual screech as she slipped inside. The house was dark and silent. On the small kitchen table, propped against the salt shaker, was a piece of paper from Leo’s sketchbook. It was a drawing of her, standing alone on a stage, a single spotlight on her. Her mouth was open, and from it flowed not a stream of musical notes, but a grey, winding path that snaked up and up, transforming into a range of hills under a starry sky. At the bottom, in his careful, neat handwriting, were the words: ‘You sounded like home. Well done, El.’ A lump formed in her throat. She sank into a chair, the drawing in one hand, the business card in the other. Down there was reality, she had thought on the moor. But she was beginning to realise she had been wrong. She didn't have to choose between the run and the reality. She could bring the moor down into the valley. She could make her life her own song. The descent was over. Now, it was time for the climb.

Sleep did not come. Elara remained at the kitchen table as the deep, silent blue of the night slowly bled into the thin, grey light of morning. The house began to wake around her, sighing and creaking into the new day. The central heating boiler gave a low groan from the cupboard under the stairs. She heard the floorboards above her creak as her mother got out of bed. The exhaustion was a physical weight now, pressing down on her shoulders, making her eyelids feel like they were lined with lead. She folded Leo’s drawing carefully and slid it, along with the business card, into the pocket of her jeans.

Her mum entered the kitchen, already dressed in her pale blue carer’s uniform. She moved with a familiar, weary economy, filling the kettle, reaching for a mug. She didn't speak for a full minute, allowing the comfortable silence of their shared mornings to settle. Then, she sat down opposite Elara, her gaze taking in her daughter’s pale, drawn face. “You’re home,” she said. It wasn’t a question.

“I didn’t win,” Elara said, the words flat and toneless in the quiet room.

Her mum reached across the formica and placed a hand over Elara’s. Her skin was dry and chapped from constant washing. “I never expected you to, pet,” she said, her voice gentle, devoid of the weary cynicism of the other night. “That doesn’t mean I’m not proud. I heard a clip on the local radio news this morning. Just a few seconds. They said… they said a girl from Milton silenced the hall.” A faint, rare smile touched her mother’s lips. “Silenced the hall. That’s my girl.” The pride was there, raw and unmistakable, and it hit Elara with more force than any applause.

Elara pulled the business card from her pocket and pushed it across the table. Her mum picked it up, her brow furrowing as she read the name. “Kestrel Records. Who’s this?”

“The head judge. Paul Abbott. He wants me to go to his studio. In Sheffield. To sing for him.”

The light in her mother’s eyes flickered and dimmed, replaced by the familiar, guarded look of someone who had learned not to trust good fortune. “Sheffield,” she repeated, the word hanging in the air like an obstacle. “Elara, be careful. Please. Men like that, in that world… they make a lot of promises. Don’t go pinning all your hopes on a piece of card. It’s a long way to fall.”

“I know, Mum,” Elara said, though the words felt like a defence against her mother’s love, not her criticism. “He said it wasn’t an offer. Just an invitation.”

“An invitation,” her mother repeated softly, turning the card over in her fingers as if weighing it. “Well. Invitations are nice. Just remember who you are, eh? And where your home is.” She gave Elara’s hand a final, firm squeeze, then stood up as the kettle clicked off. The moment was over, reality reasserting itself in the form of instant coffee and a long shift of looking after other people’s parents.

The mood in The Spinner’s Arms that evening was strange. The pickle jar was gone from the bar, and a few of the regulars offered her awkward pats on the back. “Bad luck, love.” “You was robbed.” “Should’ve sung something more cheerful.” They meant well, but their commiserations felt like epitaphs for a dream that had died. It was Brenda who swept the pity away with a brisk wipe of the bar top. “What’s all this, then? A wake? She didn’t win the bloody lottery, she went and sang her heart out on a massive stage. Did you see her? Our Elara! Looked like a star.” She beamed at Elara, her loyalty as solid and unshakeable as her peroxide beehive.

Later, when the pub quieted, Elara showed her the business card. Brenda squinted at it, her bright red lipstick pursed in concentration. “Kestrel Records,” she read aloud. “Sheffield. Paul Abbott. Him with the tired eyes. He looked like the only one who was actually listening.” She tapped the card with a long, painted nail. “Now this, this is different. Telly shows are froth. This is business. This is a proper chance.” She looked at Elara, her expression suddenly serious. “You’re going, obviously.”

“I don’t know, Bren. It’s the money for the train, another day off…”

Brenda cut her off with a wave of her hand. “Don’t be daft. I’ll cover your shift, and we’ll get you to Sheffield. George won a tenner on the horses. He’ll want to chip in.” Her gaze was firm, leaving no room for argument. “Your mum’s worried, I expect. Thinks you’ll get your heart broken.” Elara nodded. “Well, maybe you will,” Brenda said, with surprising bluntness. “But it’s better to get your heart broken chasing something real than to let it slowly starve to death pulling pints for us lot, isn’t it?”

The next morning, the urge to run was a physical craving. She needed the clean pain, the sharp air, the vast, empty space to think. She set off before dawn, her feet finding their familiar, crunching rhythm on the shale path. The ascent was punishing, her body still heavy with exhaustion, but she pushed on. As she ran, she didn’t listen to music. She listened to the competing voices in her head. Her mum’s caution, Brenda’s fierce optimism, Leo’s unwavering faith. *People like us don't get these chances. Don't you dare come back without winning. You sounded like home.* And above them all, Paul’s words: *Your voice has the bloody hills in it.*

What did that mean? She tried to feel it, to understand the connection between the strain in her legs, the controlled burn in her diaphragm, and the notes she produced. She crested the rise, the point she always aimed for, and stopped, her hands on her hips, dragging in the cold, cleansing air. Milton was laid out below, a spill of grubby Lego bricks waking in the pale morning light. This place. This hard, stubborn, beautiful, disappointing place. It was in her bones. The resilience it took to live here, the secret histories held in the soot-blackened mills, the quiet dignity of people like her mum and Brenda. It was all part of the story. Her song had not been about escaping it. It had been about claiming it.

A new melody surfaced in her mind, unbidden. It wasn't a cover, not a half-remembered folk tune. It was simpler. It had the rhythm of her feet on the path, the cadence of the wind over the reservoir. It was just a few notes, a hook without words, but it was hers. It felt like a spring bubbling up through the hard ground. She hummed it, then sang it out loud, her voice a thread of sound in the grey expanse. It wasn't polished or perfect. It was a question, a statement, a beginning. It was the sound of the run.

Back in the silence of the kitchen, the house empty for the day, she took out the business card. Her hands were steady now. The fear was still there, a low hum of anxiety in her stomach, but it was overshadowed by something else: a quiet, determined resolve. Brenda was right. It was better to risk a broken heart than to let it starve. She picked up her cheap mobile phone, its screen cracked in one corner. Her fingers trembled slightly as she dialled the number on the card, her heart pounding a frantic, desperate solo against her ribs.

A calm, professional voice answered. "Kestrel Records."

Elara took a deep breath, the kind that fuelled a final sprint. "Hello," she said, her voice clearer and stronger than she expected. "My name is Elara Vance. I'm calling for Paul Abbott. He… he gave me an invitation."

Thursday. Two o’clock. The two words had become a fixed point in Elara’s week, a monolith around which the rest of her life swirled in a familiar, frantic pattern. The days leading up to it were a blur of pulling pints and wiping down tables, of helping Leo with his homework and listening to her mum’s tired reports from the care home. But beneath the surface of the mundane, something had shifted. The secret of the appointment sat in her chest like a held breath, a mixture of pure terror and a bright, dangerous excitement. The new melody, the one born on the moor, was a constant companion now, a ghost of a tune that she would hum under her breath while stacking glasses or walking home in the dark. It was a fragile, unformed thing, and the thought of presenting it to a man like Paul Abbott felt like showing someone a single, uncertain seedling and claiming it would one day be a forest.

The journey to Sheffield felt starkly different from the one to Manchester. There was no send-off party this time, just a twenty-pound note pressed into her hand by Brenda before her shift, and a fierce hug from Leo at the front door that morning. She was completely alone on the rattling Transpennine train, watching as the familiar, steep-sided valleys of home flattened out into the wider, more sprawling urban landscape of South Yorkshire. Sheffield rose from the haze, not with the gleaming, modern indifference of Manchester, but with a similar red-brick stoicism to Milton, just on a vastly larger scale. It was a city built on steel, and she could feel the weight of its industrial past in the air, a history that felt somehow cousin to the cotton mills she had left behind. This felt less like a trip to another planet and more like visiting a bigger, tougher, more worldly relative. It was no less intimidating.

Kestrel Records was not located in a shiny city-centre office block. Following the instructions Paul had given her over the phone, Elara found herself in a part of the city that tourists never saw, a network of cobbled streets and old brick warehouses near the canal. The air smelled of damp stone and diesel. She found the address, a large, anonymous-looking former cutlery works with dark, multi-paned windows. The only sign was a small, tarnished brass plate next to a heavy black door, so discreet she almost missed it: ‘Kestrel Records’. Taking a deep, shuddering breath, she pushed the door open. It wasn't locked. The sense of anticlimax was profound.

The interior was a cavernous, dimly lit space that smelled of dust, old wood, and the faint, metallic tang of hot electronics. Wires snaked across the floor like thick black vines, connecting stacks of amplifiers and mysterious-looking boxes with blinking lights. In one corner, a collection of vintage guitars hung on a wall like hunting trophies. It was a workshop, not a waiting room. A young man with a thick beard and headphones around his neck looked up from a tangle of cables and gave her a brief, uninterested nod. Before she could announce herself, a door opened at the far end of the room and Paul Abbott emerged, holding a mug of tea. He wore the same kind of unremarkable jumper and jeans as before. He looked tired, but his eyes were sharp. “Elara,” he said, his voice calm. “You’re on time. Good. Come through.”

He led her into a smaller room, the studio’s inner sanctum. It was dominated by a vast mixing desk covered in a galaxy of knobs and sliders, facing a large window that looked into a sound-proofed live room. The silence in here was absolute, a dead, padded quiet that felt heavier than any noise. It was the kind of silence that forced you to listen to the frantic beat of your own heart. “Right then,” Paul said, gesturing for her to follow him into the live room. “No audience, no judges, no confetti. Just a microphone.” The room was stark, carpeted in a neutral grey, with a few microphone stands and a solitary wooden stool. “Let’s start with what I know. Sing me the song from the final.”

Standing in front of the expensive, sensitive-looking microphone, with a pair of heavy headphones clamped over her ears, was more terrifying than facing the entire Manchester auditorium. Through the headphones, she could hear her own breathing, ragged and loud. She could hear the faint rustle of her sleeve against her side. It was clinical, exposed. There was nowhere to hide. She swallowed, closed her eyes, and tried to summon the moor. She tried to picture the shale path, the grey sky, her brother’s drawing. She took a breath, the one she had taught herself, and sang ‘The Heather and the Stone’. Her voice came back at her through the headphones, unnervingly clear and close, every tiny imperfection laid bare. The final note faded, and the silence that followed was not empty, but analytical.

“Okay,” Paul’s voice crackled in her ears from the control room. “The control is excellent. But you’re performing it. You’re trying to sell it to an audience that isn’t there. This time, just sing it to yourself. Forget I’m here. Find the core of it.” The instruction was both confusing and clarifying. She had spent so long thinking of her voice as something to be projected, to be sent out. The idea of pulling it inward was new. She tried again, focusing not on the power, but on the meaning of the words, the quiet stubbornness of the lyric. It felt smaller, more vulnerable, but somehow truer. When she finished, Paul’s voice came back after a long pause. “Better. Much better. That’s the truth of it.”

A wave of relief so profound it made her dizzy washed over her. He got it. He actually understood. She watched through the glass as he leaned forward, speaking to the bearded engineer. Then, his voice was back in her ears, calm and direct. “All right. That proves you can repeat it. It’s not a fluke. But I don’t sign singers, Elara. I sign artists. A singer can repeat a performance. An artist has a point of view. So. What else have you got?” This was the moment. The precipice. Her mind raced through the old folk songs, the pub ballad. They felt like borrowed clothes, things that belonged to someone else’s past. They were not her point of view. Her throat went dry. The silence stretched. She was going to fail. She had nothing.

“There’s… there’s one other thing,” she heard herself say, the words a thin, reedy whisper. “It’s not finished. It doesn’t even have words, really. It’s just…” She trailed off, unable to explain. In the control room, Paul leaned back in his chair, his expression unreadable, and simply waited. It was a terrifying, absolute patience. She had to fill the silence. Taking a breath that felt like leaping from a cliff, she closed her eyes one more time. She didn't think of the moor or the audience or the microphone. She just thought of the rhythm of her own two feet on the path home. She let the simple, unadorned melody out, the one she had found in the pre-dawn quiet. It was a short, looping phrase, raw and unresolved, full of a quiet, yearning melancholy. It felt impossibly small and naked in the vast silence of the studio.
